result.execSummary:
The defendant was charged with both OWI (3rd) and Operating w/ PAC (3rd). The defendant was found guilty of OWI (3rd) and the other charge, Operating w/ PAC (3rd) was dismissed by the court.

  • Daniel Sanchez Jr. was found guilty of OWI (3rd), an unclassified misdemeanor, Wisconsin Statutes 346.63(1)(a).
  • Daniel Sanchez Jr. was found guilty of Operating While Revoked (Rev due to alc/contr subst/refusal), an unclassified misdemeanor, Wisconsin Statutes 343.44(1)(b).

Charge(s) in this case were read in to this or other case(s). A "read in" charge is a charge that is dismissed as part of a plea agreement, however:

  • The defendant agrees to have the court consider the charge(s) when sentencing for another crime, under Wis. Stats. 973.20(1g)(b); and
  • The defendant cannot be prosecuted for these charge(s) in the future.

Notice to employers: It may be a violation of state law to discriminate against a job applicant because of an arrest or conviction record. Generally speaking, an employer may refuse to hire an applicant on the basis of a conviction only if the circumstances of the conviction substantially relate to the particular job. For more information, see Wisconsin Statute 111.335 and the Department of Workforce Development's publication, Arrest and Conviction Records under the Law.

supervisions.notes:
*Pay fine plus costs
*Payment plan to be set up for fines and costs 60 days from release from prison
*Defendant is required to authorize the department to collect funds from the defendant's wages and from other moneys held in the defendant's prisoner's account to be used for payment of obligations in reasonable amounts as determined by DOC. If any fines, costs, surcharges, & restitution remain outstanding at the end of the confinement portion of this sentence, then the remaining balances shall be paid as a condition of extended supervision.  If discharged with outstanding financial obligations, a civil Judgment will be entered against the Defendant in favor of restitution victims and/or governmental entities for the balance due. All available enforcement actions will be used to collect the debt.

*Credit for any time revoked administratively

original filed in 16CF347
Plea hearing on April 5, 2017 at 08:30 am.
Defendant Record Update
Pre-trial conference on January 17, 2017 at 08:30 am.

Defendant Daniel Sanchez in court with attorney Ryan Drengler. David R. Knaapen appeared for the State of Wisconsin.
Cases heard today are 16CF347, 16CF449, 16CM230, 15CM515, 15CM516 and 15CT213.

9:19 a.m.  Atty Knaapen calls the case and states the appearances.

Atty Knaapen states that there had been a plea agreement but Atty Drengler had informed the State that he is not able to proceed today.
Atty Drengler indicates that his client has been "shopping" around for private counsel.
Atty Drengler moves the Court to allow him to withdraw as counsel.
Court indicates that a motion to withdraw will need to be provided to the Court for signature.
Defendant indicates that he has spoken with Atty Redfield on 12/06/16.
Court makes additional statements in regards to the cases in front of the Court.

BTC:  Atty Drengler is not allowed to withdraw as of today's date but will need to file a motion to withdraw.
Court will look for a stipulation for substitution of counsel if defendant so chooses to obtain other counsel.  Pre-trial conference scheduled for January 17, 2017 at 08:30 am.
